questions.solution:
Explanation:

Baby-farming (Homicidal Starvation)

  • Historical practice where infants-often illegitimate-;were placed under someone's care in exchange for money.
  • Many were deliberately neglected or starved to death for profit, making it essentially a form of commercial infanticide.

Accidental Starvation

  • Occurs unintentionally when individuals are deprived of food due to disasters or catastrophic events.
  • Common causes include being trapped during earthquakes, landslides, or suffering from famine and flooding.

Suicidal Starvation (Hunger Strike)

  • Voluntary refusal to eat, usually as a form of protest.
  • Typically seen in prisoners who withhold food to draw attention or achieve a goal.
  • Medically, a hunger strike involves refusing food (but typically still consuming water), and can lead to serious health risks if prolonged.

questions.text: In acute starvation feeling of intense hunger lasts
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In acute starvation, there is a feeling of hunger and the hunger pain (Hunger pangs) lasts in about 30 to 48 hours but thirst becomes intense.
  • After 4 to 5 days of starvation, general emaciation and absorption of the subcutaneous fat begins to occur.

questions.text: In both water and food are completely withheld to a person, death usually occurs in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Total deprivation of water and food results death in about 10 to 12 days.
  • Newborns may survive for 7 to 10 days without food and water.
  • If food alone is withdrawn, death may occur in 6 to 8 weeks or even more.

questions.text: In starvation, loss of______% of protein is fatal.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Death usually occurs when about 80% of body fat, and 20% of body protein are lost.
  • Life is threatened when more than 40 per cent of the original body weight has been lost, though the speed of loss is relevant.

questions.text: In starvation, the gall bladder may be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In case of starvation, the gallbladder is distended with bile, as the bile is not used.
    In prolonged fasting or starvation, the gallbladder becomes distended, as bile accumulates due to lack of cholecystokinin (CCK) stimulation to trigger contraction.
  • The heart is small from brown atrophy, and chambers are empty.
  • Brain is the only organ which does not show reduction in size and weight.
  • Loss of adipose tissue from the omentum, mesentery and perirenal fat stores.
  • Gut is empty and filled with gas. The wall is contracted and translucent from stomach to colon. The walls of the intestine may appear like tissue paper(considered to be the sure sign).
  • Faecoliths are usually present and may ulcerate the intestinal linings.
  • Bones may show features of demineralization. Stress fractures are present.
  • All the organs shrink except the brain.

questions.text: Autopsy of a patient shows an entire absence of fat in the omentum, mesentery, and internal organs. Which of the following most likely leads to this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In starvation, the loss of adipose tissue will also be evident internally in the internal fat depots like omentum, mesentery and perirenal fat. This is never seen in wasting diseases and cancer.

Cancer (Cachexia) (Option B):Cachexia leads to significant weight loss and fat depletion, but it typically doesn't eliminate internal fat depots entirely,omentum and mesenteric fat are usually still present

Liposuction (Option C):Liposuction targets subcutaneous fat, not visceral fat deep inside the body. It does not remove fat from omentum or mesentery in routine cosmetic procedures

Wasting Diseases (Option D):Conditions like chronic illnesses result in general fat and muscle loss. However, they do not cause complete absence of all internal fat storage areas such as the omental and mesenteric depots.

questions.text: During starvation, the energy source for heart is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acetoacetate (and β-hydroxybutyrate) are key ketone bodies produced by the liver during prolonged fasting or starvation. The heart efficiently uses these ketone bodies as an alternative energy source when glucose is scarce
  • Among ketones, acetoacetate is especially important; it's converted into acetyl-CoA in cardiac cells to fuel the citric acid cycle and generate ATP

Fat (Free Fatty Acids) (Option A):Under normal conditions, the heart primarily relies on fatty acids and glucose for energy. But during starvation, when glucose is low, ketone bodies become the preferred fuel.

Amino acids(Option B):In starvation, amino acids are mainly broken down for gluconeogenesis (producing glucose to maintain blood sugar). They aren't the primary energy substrate for the heart

Proteins(Option D):Proteins themselves are not used directly for energy. They are degraded into amino acids, which then serve mainly in glucose production-not as direct power sources for the heart

Reference:https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/acetoacetic-acid

questions.text: Last subcutaneous adipose tissue to disappear in case of starvation is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bichat's (Buccal) Fat Pad is a specialized encapsulated mass of fat located in the cheeks, between the buccinator and masseter muscles.

In cases of prolonged starvation (e.g., marasmus), general emaciation and subcutaneous fat depletion occur early, leading to sunken cheeks and visible bony facial structures

Facial changes become pronounced:

  • Eyes appear sunken and glisten.
  • Pupils may appear dilated.
  • Cheeks hollow out, and underlying bones become more visible.

Breast (Option A):Contains both fatty and glandular components. Fat loss occurs gradually but breast fat is not the most resistant; it depletes earlier than Bichat's pad.

Abdomen (Option C):Abdominal fat includes both subcutaneous and visceral fat, which tends to diminish earlier during overall fat loss and is not especially resistant in starvation.

Buttock (Option D):Composed of gluteofemoral subcutaneous fat that typically depletes alongside general subcutaneous fat, rather than being a late-preserving depot like Bichat's pad.

questions.text: An old man who was lying on the roadside is brought to the casualty by the police. On detailed history, he reveals that he has had no food for the past few weeks. On examination, he is severely emaciated. What is the likely finding in the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario points to starvation. In this condition, the gall bladder is distended.

  • In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. Hence, bill gets accumulated in the gall bladder which gets distended.
  • In acute starvation, there is a feeling of hunger for the first 30 to 48 hours,
  • If both water and food are completely withdrawn death occurs in 10 to 12 days.
  • If food alone is withdrawn death occurs in 6 to 8 weeks or even more.
  • Death usually occurs when about 80 of body fat, and 20% of body protein are lost.
  • Newborns may survive for 7 to 10 days without food or water.
  • Life is threatened when more than 40 per cent of the original body weight has been lost, though the speed of loss is relevant (BK).
  • There is a reduction in the weight and size of all organs except the brain.

questions.text: A person is sitting on fast unto death. As a doctor you will not allow the person to die because of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Article 21 guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, and explicitly does not include a 'right to die'. Therefore, a doctor is legally justified in intervening to preserve life,even overriding the person's wish to fast unto death, as that would violate this fundamental right.

Article 21 of Constitution of India:

  • This ensures Right to life but does not include right to die.
  • So forcible feeding of persons going on hunger strike is lawful in India

Declaration of Malta (Option A):This deals with the Respect the autonomy of the patient and suggests that the doctor should not feed forcibly in such cases. Feeding is allowed when the patient has lapsed into coma

Declaration of Sydney (Option B):Deals with the determination of death and the recovery of organs

Article 14 of the Constitution of India (Option D ):"The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India".Pertains to equality before the law and equal protection, not to the right to life or decisions regarding medical interventions.

Explanation:

Falanga (Falaka, Bastinado):

  • In this canes or rod are used to beat on the soles of the feet, or rarely to the palms of the hands or hips, which is very painful and debilitating. Contusions are found deep in the tissues.
  • It is a type of physical torture.

Physical Torture:

  1. Beatings & Falanga (Foot Whipping): Blows to the body or soles of feet-causing excruciating pain and potential motor nerve damage.
  2. Electric Shocks & Burns: Applied using electrical currents or heated tools for sharp pain with few visible marks.
  3. Asphyxiation & Water-Based Methods (e.g., Waterboarding): Techniques that block breathing or simulate drowning, inflicting severe physical and psychological distress
  4. Walling: A torture method where the victim is slammed (via collar leverage) into a flexible or false wall-inflicts force trauma, especially to shoulder and neck.
  5. Mutilation, Burns & Temperature Exposure: Includes cutting, branding, burning, and exposure to extreme heat or cold-designed to inflict long-lasting harm

Mental torture:

  1. Solitary confinement in a dark place.
  2. Blindfolding for a long time, or frequent transfer from one place to another blindfolded.
  3. Starving the victim.
  4. Causing mental anguish by giving false information to victim regarding tragedy involving wife and children.
  5. Enforced use of psychotropic drugs.

Sexual torture:

  1. Infliction of injuries to private parts or introducing foreign bodies into the rectum or vagina, or mutilation of breasts or genitals.
  2. Raping the victim or undressing before others, or sexually tortured by trained animals, etc.
  3. Suspension of weights on the penis and scrotum.
  4. Forced sex with convicts.
  5. Application of chilli powder or other irritants to genitalia.

Tying a plastic bag over the head (Dry Submarine) involves suffocating the victim by obstructing their airways-this method is distinctively known as the "dry submarine" form of asphyxiation.

Beating on the sole of the feet is known as Falanga or Falaka or Bastinado.(Option A)

In Wet submarine (Latina), head is submerged in polluted water.(Option C)

Inserting heated metal skewer into the anus is known as Black slave.(Option D)

Explanation:

  • Telefono a torture technique involving forceful slapping to both ears simultaneously, typically with cupped hands, resulting in rapid pressure increase within the ear canal and often leading to tympanic membrane rupture and hearing damage
  • Tying Legs & thighs tightly with bamboo sticks is known as Chepuwa.This method involves clamping the legs or thighs tightly with bamboo for sustained pain, not ear trauma.(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A person in police custody was placed in prone position with his wrist & ankles bound behind his back and secured by a cord. This method is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hog-tying (total appendage restraint procedure): It is a type of physical restraint in which the person is placed in prone position with his wrists and ankles bound behind his back and secured by a cord. The person may have difficulty in breathing or may become unresponsive.

Choke (Bar Arm) Hold

  • Forearm placed across front of neck; free hand grips wrist and pulls back.
  • Blocks airway + carotid arteries → immediate unconsciousness.
  • Hypopharynx occluded by tongue displacement.
  • Risk: hyoid/larynx fracture, rare death from hypoxia or catecholamine-induced arrhythmia.
  • Carotid body pressure may cause sudden cardiac arrest.

Carotid Sleeper Hold (Lateral Vascular Neck Restraint)

  • From behind: arm around neck, antecubital fossa at midline; free hand grips wrist and pulls back.
  • Compresses carotid & jugular, spares vertebral arteries & trachea.
  • Unconscious in 10-15 sec, recovery in 10-20 sec after release.
  • Neck structures undamaged; rare death from hypoxia/catecholamine release.

Falanga (Bastinado, Falaka)

  • Beating soles of feet (sometimes palms/hips) with cane/rod.
  • Causes deep tissue contusions, faint red lines, later hyperpigmentation.
  • Extremely painful and debilitating.

questions.text: A form of electrical torture is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

La Parrilla (torture device):

  • The La parrilla is a method of torture where the victim is strapped to a metal frame and subjected to electric shock.
  • The Spanish word parrilla means a cooking grill or barbecue of the type commonly found in South American countries. By gruesome analogy, the metal frame used in the torture was given the same name because of its appearance and because the victim was placed on top of it like the meat on a barbecue. The parrilla is both the metal frame and the method of torture that uses it.

Chepuwa:

  • The legs and thighs are tied very tightly with bamboo sticks, etc., to induce severe pain.

Parrot's perch (Jack):

  • Head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrists bound to the ankle

Ghotna:

  • It involves rolling a wooden log or iron rod up and down the thighs, while the log is weighted by one or two policemen standing on it.
  • This causes rupture of muscle fibres and blood vessels. severe pain and often unconsciousness and the victims are unable to walk for several weeks.
  • The ghotna may also be applied by placing it behind the knees and then forcibly flexing the legs over it.
